Award.AwardTitle: AF: SMALL: Provable Algorithms for Nonhermitian Matrices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix is among the most
fundamental computational tasks. These quantities correspond to resonant
frequencies and modes of physical, statistical, and mathematical systems and
appear in essentially every area of science and engineering. First year
college students are taught how to compute them on small examples, and two of
the ``top 10 algorithms of the twentieth century'' --- the QR Algorithm and
the Arnoldi algorithm --- were designed to do so on large instances. When the
matrices involved are symmetric, these methods come with provable guarantees
showing that they are accurate, fast, and correct. However, the general
non-symmetric case remains poorly understood, and rigorously analyzing these
algorithms in general has been a decades-old mystery in numerical analysis,
despite their being implemented in standard software packages. The main goal
of this project is to solve these and related mysteries using modern tools of
random-matrix theory and theoretical computer science. Doing so will put a
large branch of computational practice on solid theoretical footing, and
ideally foster deeper interaction between the numerical analysis, mathematics,
and theoretical computer science research communities.

Specifically, the project will aim to analyze the two (currently heuristic)
algorithms mentioned above, with the following concrete major goals: (1) find
a shifting strategy for the shifted QR method which provably converges rapidly
for every matrix; (2) formalize a widely held belief precisely relating the
output of the Arnoldi algorithm to the pseudospectrum of the input matrix.
Secondarily, the award will study the adjacent problem of efficiently
computing an approximation of the Jordan normal form of a given rational
matrix in the variable precision model of computation, for which good
complexity bounds are not known. The project will likely use techniques from
random-matrix theory, dynamical systems, algebra, and numerical analysis,
building on recent progress of the investigator and collaborators in some of
these areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are the mathematical concepts corresponding to resonant frequencies and modes in physics, and appear throughout mathematics, science, and engineering. The main scientific activities of this proposal fall in two related categories: the development and rigorous analysis of algorithms for efficiently computing the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrices, and the study of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of adjacency matrices of graphs.

In the first category, our main activity was to study the “Shifted QR” algorithm of Francis and Kublanovskaya from the late 1950’s. This is the most widely used algorithm for computing the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a dense matrix, implemented in all major software libraries. It is a bit like the simplex algorithm for linear programming in that it is specified by a "shifting strategy" (cf. pivoting strategies for simplex). It was shown in the late 1960s that there is a strategy – known as the Wilkinson shift – which converges rapidly and provably when the input is a Hermitian matrix, but no strategy was known to be provably rapidly convergent on every input matrix. Apart from being a tantalizing theoretical mystery, this meant that software based on Shifted QR was not guaranteed to work, and indeed was observed to occasionally fail in practice. We made significant progress on this question by giving a new strategy which converges rapidly and provably on a small random perturbation of every input matrix. We further proved that this strategy continues to have guaranteed performance when implemented in floating point arithmetic with a reasonable bound on the number of bits of precision used. There is hope that a variant of our strategy can be used to make software libraries for computing eigenvalues more reliable.

In the second category, we studied the following three questions, which are all related to understanding the structure of graphs via the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of their adjacency matrices:

(a)    How well-connected is the graph formed by the edges of a polytope (feasible set of a linear program) with few constraints? Proving that this graph has small diameter (as a function of the number of constraints) is a long-standing question in discrete geometry, known as the Hirsch conjecture.

(b)    How large can the multiplicity (degeneracy) of the second eigenvalue of a sparse graph be? The second eigenvalue is important because it is related to how well-connected the graph is, and its multiplicity is relevant to questions in discrete geometry.

(c)     How “oscillatory” are the eigenvectors of sparse random graphs? This is articulated by counting the number of connected subgraphs of the graph where the eigenvector does not change sign, known as nodal domains. Nodal domains are a classical topic in pure mathematics, of interest in mathematical physics.

We made significant progress on each of these questions via new approaches to them. In (a) we studied a certain Schrodinger operator on the relevant graph, which we proved had favorable spectral properties for reasons related to convex geometry. In (b) we developed a new probabilistic argument for controlling the distribution of mass of eigenvectors of graphs. In (c) we combined tools from random matrix theory, combinatorics, and graph limits in a way which allowed us to overcome earlier barriers to accessing the number of nodal domains.

The above activities were accompanied by an extensive dissemination plan centered around the first category of contributions. To bridge the gap between the theoretical computer science and applied mathematics communities in this area, the PI co-organized an online seminar series called “Complexity of Matrix Computations” in Summer 2021, which consisted of panel discussions among leading experts in both fields on foundational issues of common interest. There were ten seminars in total with an average of about 100 attendees each. As a followup, the PI co-organized a week long program called “Perspectives on Matrix Computations: Theoretical Computer Science meets Numerical Analysis” at Banff in March, 2023, as well as a 2 day workshop called “Perspectives on Eigenvalue Computation” at the 2023 AMS Joint Math Meetings. The PI is co-organizing a semester-long program on “Complexity of Matrix Computations”, scheduled to take place in Fall 2025 at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing. The PI wrote a survey article explaining the state of the art around the matrix diagonalization problem (including the results on Shifted QR mentioned above) aimed towards a broad audience of computer scientists and pure and applied mathematicians. Four graduate students received their PhDs doing research under this award.
